captions.text:
00:01
Janice: I am their mother as far as they're

concerned. I am mummy. They'll rub my face,
they'll let me kiss them on the nose.

00:07
COMM: Having pet cats may sound run of the

mill, but Janice Haley has taken her love
of felines to the extreme, keeping two huge
tigers in her back garden.

00:18
COMM: Sabre, a 600lb male white bengal and

Janda, a 400lb bengal female, have lived with
Janice since they were cubs.

00:28
COMM: Despite tigers having a fearsome reputation,

Janice has never been short of people wanting
to help out.

00:38
Janice: Pretty much everyone comes here to

interact with them. My volunteers are all
basically part of my family.

00:43
COMM: Like most young males, Sabre can get

a little boisterous, but that's not enough
to keep Carrie Ates from helping out.

00:50
Carrie: I don't get scared when the tigers

are dragging me around the cage. They're doing
it in play and it's a relationship we have,

especially Sabre, I've been there with him
since he was two weeks old and have gone through
all the raising and training with him.

01:08
Carrie: The playtime is good for them and

they don't make it scary. He's not aggressive
when he's dragging me around, he's doing it

out of our relationship and it continues the
bond I guess.

01:18
COMM: 57-year-old Janice and her husband David

work around the clock to care for 6-year-old
Sabre and 12-year-old Janda.

01:26
Janice: Hi, you going to let mummy in?

01:29
COMM: But only happened upon their extraordinary

life when she decided to quit her boring day
job.

01:34
Janice: This adventure began back in 1995

when I was working behind a desk doing tedious
work and I really wanted to get back outside

and my husband came up with the idea of working
with these wild exotic animals.

01:45
COMM: Janice understands people may disagree

with her decision to keep the tigers in captivity,
but says Sabre and Janda have a good quality
of life.

01:55
Janice: People who consider it cruel to keep

them in captivity have a point to a point.
It is not the idea for a tiger to be, but

in this point in the wild there is no hope
for them out there anymore.

02:07
Janice: If there aren't some of them still

left in cages, there aren't any going to be
left at all in a couple of years from now.

02:13
Janice: We hand feed them three times a day

every single day and they are provided for
and loved here.

02:18
Janice: In my opinion I wouldn't mind being
a tiger in my backyard.

02:21
COMM: After spending more than 12 hours caring

for Janda and Sabre, Janice can finally try
and get some rest for herself before it all
starts again tomorrow.

02:32
Janice: Nighty-night guys, see you in the
morning. Have a good night, love you.

title: Florida Woman Keeps Bengal Tigers In Her Garden

comments.text:
She thinks the cats see her their "mother."  Stupid, STUPID women.  Great 
for the cats though, as they eventually will have themselves two tasty 
meals whenever the killer instinct that's imprinted in their DNA  flashes 
in their predatory brain cells.  

Even the most domesticated house cat who has been born with humans and 
lived with humans its whole life will instinctively lash out and scratch 
its owner.  Now just imagine a 600 lb tiger with paws and claws the size of 
her head doing that.  Sorry, everything points to the conclusion that these 
two women may have warm fuzzy altruistic intentions, but they are dumb as a 
slab of red meat at some point will wind up as a devoured slab of red meat.﻿

comments.text:
did you not learn anything from this video at all. these tigers have been 
trained since they were cubs and treat these people like family and do NOT 
want to harm them. and these people have been playing with them long enough 
for them to know not what to do. is it possible for them to make a mistake 
one day or one day have an outburst of anger, yes, but that goes for every 
single living being besides plants. we as human make mistakes, and lose 
control of our anger just like any other animal. your acting like these 
animals, have no brain, no thinking process whatsoever, and no learning 
process to know what is right and wrong. when do you hear of other tigers 
being killed by tigers besides when they are protecting their territory. 
cubs do not hurt each other when they are playing with each other and adult 
tigers to not kill one another when playing either.

and i am not basing this on personal feelings, this is all comes from how 
these tigers were raised.

comments.text:
I've rescuded 2 domestic cats for a worse life than the could have had 
without me, nevertheless, I kept feeling guilty with keeping them indoors, 
I do not have a garden..... it is what is, one was 14 years in my care 
until he passed away, the oldest, gotten in the shelter is now 18 years 
old. I have made the decision for them it would be better for them to be 
with me instead of living on the streets (the one who passed away) or in a 
shelter (my old cat of 18 years. I've struggled with the question, is it 
okay to denie them a yard, on the other hand, maybe they would never ended 
up in one. (me, i have decided for them, did I do the right thing?)
In this case (the video) I do not agree, if searched, a whole better 
enviroment could be found for WILD animals, this is not a domestic cat and 
yet, people mean good but in my mind, they should think a lot more of the 
well-being of these enou-rmous, beautiful wild animals, who need a lot more 
than hugs to be happy, it has to hunt, live out it's natural born habbits, 
be wild, go hunting and so much more.
When it comes to animalrights, I am glad to life in Europe, we are way 
beyond in exposing and having this sort of animals in our homes. Thank god.﻿
